Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Interactive 3-D Technical Illustrations for Science and Engineering
Award.AbstractNarration:
The innovation in this Phase II Project will develop tools for creating, displaying, and publishing interactive 3D content. The resulting technology will empower educators, students, publishers, and businesses to easily produce interactive 3D illustrations for digital books and online education materials. A unique approach to this long-standing content creation problem centers around the use of Image-Based Modeling and Rendering (IBMR), which enables the creation of highly realistic digital 3D models using commodity smartphones instead of the complex dedicated hardware systems traditionally required. Building on technology developed during the associated Phase I Project, this research aims to: develop new algorithms for creating interactive illustrations that place fewer assumptions on the hardware used to create them, develop algorithms for extracting 3D geometry from image sequences, and develop new methods for capturing unique panoramic image sets that can be used in an educational context. The resulting technology platform will make interactive 3D content widely-accessible by significantly reducing the expertise and cost currently required during its creation.

The broader/commercial impact of this project is to make user-generated 3D content part of the revolution in digital and online education by simplify the creation process and making it widely accessible to a non-technical audience. The core technology developed in this proposal has application areas spanning from education and cultural heritage to consumer marketing and advertising. This project also includes specific outreach activities that will benefit the local community while bringing the resulting technology to the attention of the wide audience that can benefit from user-generated 3D content.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arqspin 360 photography platform (http://arqspin.com) is the most significant outcome of this SBIR award. Arqspin consists of a collection of web- and mobile-based software tools for creating, authoring, editing, and publishing interactive image-based 360s that have become ubiquitous on the Internet in the last five years. This platform uses multiple technological advancements in image-based representations developed through with funding from this SBIR award, including 3D reconstruction, interactive web-based image and video editing, and GPU-based parallel processing. Arqspin provides inexperienced users with a reliable, simple, and efficient way to digitize the 3D shape and physical appearance of physical objects. Arqspin customers include a wide range of e-commerce businesses, museums, artists, and educators. More information can be found at our website http://arqspin.com including interactive examples. Examples of customers actively using Arqspin can be found on our blog http://arqspin.com/blog.

Another unanticipated outcome of this SBIR award were two mobile camera apps called FocusTwist and Vinyet that allow easily creating refocusable and short looping videos respectively. Vinyet includes an advanced real-time GPU-based video processing engine that directly arose from several of the core video processing components we developed for our Arqspin mobile applications. These apps were sold via the Apple App Store and spent multiple weeks as Top 10 Apps under the Photography section of the App Store. Vinyet has been featured 69 times in iTunes and spent months as a Top 10 app in the Photo and Video section of the App Store. FocusTwist recieved significant press attention and was briefly the #21 most popular app on the Apple App Store in the US. More information at http://focustwist.com and http://vinyet.co.
